item.title: [TICKER | EXPLODING 56.0/hr] Apart from price movement BTC is a total failure. — 14 replies
item.content:encoded:
Apart from price movement BTC is a total failure.

Open thread • Replies: 14 • Updated: 2026-02-15 20:42 UTC

OP

Early replies (first 3)

61854672
>>61854664
Yea i have crypto fatigue, but i have to keep gambling like the good golem i am

61854677
what does a bit coin do again?

I remember I wanted it to go up but I had 8 work from home jobs back then and the government kept sending me checks

61854716
>>61854664
me on the left!

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61854885
>>61854677
>what does a bit coin do again?
It makes me richer every 4 years. That's all it needs to do.

61854899
Dull.

Physical goods require active force simply to maintain ownership, trust-based assets require trusted third parties (TTPs) to operate them. Storing abstract economic value in either enables negative sum actors (NSAs) to parasite as negative sum actors can specialize exclusively in force, taking physical goods by force and either coercing TTPs, or using force to BECOME the TTP (the origin of State). Positive sum actors had to either reduce their own production to make time for murdering/imprisoning/exiling NSAs, pay extortion to them, or employ positive sum actors specializing in force (police/military), however, as abstract economic value was seizable, there was a constant selection pressure for these “immune cells” to turn malignant.

Hence the cyclic nature of empire/nation growth and decay, positive sum actors build, negative sum actors corrupt and destroy, NSAs are excised & PSAs rebuild from the ashes. As can be seen, PSAs have been at a HUGE disadvantage to NSAs through history, the best “solution” we had come up with pre-BTC was Plato’s Benevolent Philosopher King, a perfectly trustworthy trusted third party, do you have any Benevolent Philosopher Kings lying around? Not a real solution.

But by placing abstract economic value beyond the veil of voluntarity, positive sum actors can reverse the advantage. Satoshi has “fixed the glitch”, NSAs will no longer be able to parasite “so it'll just work itself out naturally”. No force, no confrontation, necessary.

Bitcoin obsolesces coercion, achieving Voluntarism not via an impossible to implement memeshit “non-aggression principle”, but by removing the systemic profitability of force.

61854912
>>61854899
>why do choose to represent Bitcoin with a round dwarf muscular cartoon man. Why not a gold coin.

61855039
>>61854899
>trying to sound like an intellectual

61855193
>>61854664
Dwarf bro is so much better than this whore. He deserves better. Why even waste his time on this basic bitch roastie? In ten years she will be fat and ugly while the dwarfmaxxxed chad will be breaking prs and probably a multimillionaire.

61855325
>>61855193
they're married

61857918
>>61855039
Post your solution to the problem of negative sum actor corruption of trusted third parties, oh, right, you have no solution. Ignoring the problem is not a solution. Bitcoin is a solution.

61857935
>>61857918
Stop, you're going to confuse the rockfags who think vaults full of rocks solves corruption and trust issues.

61857969
>>61855325
I don't care. if he hits a woman
>economically
I am going to hit him
>economically

61858009
>>61854899

61858040

>proceeds to make up nonsense reasons why bitcoin is a solution to an absolute non problem that nobody even knows exists (because it doesn't)

This still does not solve the CUSIP Conundrum. Words only get you so far, but right here right now in 2026 there are open Bed Bath and Beyond stores and the company that operates them is not even using the Overstock/BYON/BBBY CUSIP. They issued new securities in October using BBBYQs CUSIP.
It's already proven 100% fact that a reverse merger of the BBBYQ shell has already occurred with BBBY. There is zero counterargument.
Overstock, BYON and BBBY all kept them same CUSIP. So why now does it suddenly switch? Occams Razor solves the puzzle: BBBYQ shell reverse merger has already occured and the details are not in any known docket.
BBBY mystery has been solved by yours truly.

61857577
>>61857546
>What do you guys think about DK-Butterfly's CUSIP matching the new BBBY warrants?
This is quite intriguing indeed! By my best calculations, it appears that BBBYQ shell has reverse merged with BBBY. This is the only way possible the warrants would use the wrong CUSIP.
This would be like filing your taxes and you suddenly misusing the wrong social security number when filling out the paperwork. The bankers that help underwrite these securities are not guessing and using the wrong CUSIP. When the investment bankers helped in creating these warrants for distribution, at that very moment the controlling interest of BBBY was BBBYQ. It's 100% proven fact. It's a fact because we can literally check the CUSIPs right here right now. We can also go into Bed Bath and Beyond stores right here and now. We also know what a Butterfly transaction is. It's exactly what happened in this CH11. There is still much more to come!

1 - State the obvious. Reverse merger already happened. Towelkings win.
2 - State a logical explanation why the wrong CUSIP is being used on warrants in the context that we've been postulating for YEARS that this restructuring ends in a transaction. The evidence supports our thesis.
3 - Be a grumpy wumpy seethy weethy.
Those are your only options, and no, being a seethy does not solve the CUSIP Conundrum. If you can't solve the conundrum then that means we have our Cusip Confirmation.

European domestic investments do not generate remotely the same return as American ones, so the European savings just goes into the S&P as well. So what Ursula here is talking about is capital controls, forcing domestic savings into domestic investment sinks. This is not dissimilar to what China has going on, except Europeans don't have the right capital or population structure to justify domestic investment on that scale. They already have infrastructure and though we call them Europoors, they aren't nearly as destitute as the median Chinaman. It's going to be the malinvestment spectacle of the century if the EU actually manages to implement a regime to this effect, amidst some stiff competition.

61855185
based chinks
death to the u.s dollar
bring in a gold/silver standard to the yuan

61855186
>>61854357
Because ching chong ping pong

61855237
>>61854357
Their position in US treasuries is part of keeping the dollar strong vs their currency, so they can export more goods here. If people here are soon to be unemployed, due to AI doing total white-collar death, there will fewer people to buy their goods. Japan, China, and other exporters have less incentive to buy US debt if the US consumer base dries up.

61855282
Trump bullied China during his first term, and as a result we had Covid. Trump bullied China again in his second term, and as a result we have the death of the usd.
Play stupid games, win stupid prizes.

real and straight

fake and gay

item.title: [TICKER | 13.6/hr] Thread 61856272 — 21 replies
item.content:encoded:
Thread 61856272

Open thread • Replies: 21 • Updated: 2026-02-15 19:19 UTC

OP

Anons, i want to divest from the US. I see a lot of companies and people doing it. I don't want to be the last one left. I don't want to invest in crypto since a lot of countries are starting to pass regulations for it. I don't want to invest in China. Where should i put my money in? Any ideas?

Early replies (first 3)

61856281
>>61856272
invest in europe.

61856290
Invest in Japanese industry. Particularly companies that produce equipment for the nuclear energy sector

61856297
>>61856281
>invest in europe
That's very broad. Got any specific leads? People have been trying to tell me to invest in defence stocks but everyone seems to be trying to bid for those right now and i am not a big enough player.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61856302
>>61856290
Good advise. Japan is going to try and make their own nukes so they will invest more into that sector. So i guess i'll do a split between Europe and Japan. Now i just need to find the right stocks.

61856305
>>61856272
>https://www.justetf.com/en/etf-profile.html?isin=IE0006WW1TQ4
Take this as base and add some individual EM countries that you want. Mexico, South East Asia, Turkey, Argentina...your choice

61856312
>>61856297
defence isn't a bad bet. if you're looking for single companies you should look for defence adjacent industrial businesses that are now adapting their production to defence, of which there are plenty. there is also a european defence ETF by wisdromtree, but you're buying mostly rheinmetall and saab with that one.
honestly i think that you will already outperform the S&P500 with an MSCI Europe ETF for the next couple of years, especially if the USD falls further against the EUR, so i would just go with that.

61856315
>>61856290
What is it about Japan that makes white people turn into annoying third world brownoids?

61856319
>>61856272
>I don't want to invest in China
you doing it everyday

61856325
>>61856312
>MSCI Europe ETF
I would buy msci eafe etf since it gives you japan exposure too

61856335
>>61856302
Itochu, Hitachi and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries are the best options

61856338
>>61856315
It's the top tier pussy

61856339
>>61856272
you also need to factor in exchange rates, you cannot really predict what markets are going to do the best, but what you can do is invest in the markets of countries with the weakest currencies compared to their history. That way you get to invest in markets at a discount and stack the numbers in your favor.

Some good options: Japan, Australia, Mexico, Canada

61856350
Thanks for all the good advice /biz/bros.

61856370
>>61856297
EXUS is a good start.
EU Defense and finance sector broke records last year, you would be chasing those profits now.
Something to keep eye on is infra imo.

>>61856297

>>61856537
